normalised: The Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) has issued new guidelines effective first October two thousand and twenty four to enhance the security of online transactions, particularly those involving e-commerce platforms like Flipkart and Amazon. This move aims to combat the rising instances of cyber fraud and unauthorized transactions, which have reportedly cost Indian consumers approximately rupee two hundred and fifty crore in the last fiscal year.

unnormalised: One of the key changes is the mandatory implementation of tokenization for card-on-file (CoF) transactions. Previously, merchants could store customers' card details, making them vulnerable to data breaches. With tokenization, sensitive card information is replaced with a unique "token," rendering it useless to fraudsters even if a merchant's database is compromised. For every Rs. 2000 spent the likelihood of fraud increases by 1.2% according to RBI.
normalised: One of the key changes is the mandatory implementation of tokenization for card-on-file (C-o-F) transactions. Previously, merchants could store customers' card details, making them vulnerable to data breaches. With tokenization, sensitive card information is replaced with a unique "token," rendering it useless to fraudsters even if a merchant's database is compromised. For every rupees two thousand spent the likelihood of fraud increases by one point two percent according to R-B-I.

unnormalised: The RBI also emphasized the importance of two-factor authentication (2FA) for all online payments exceeding Rs. 5000. This means that in addition to entering card details, customers will need to verify the transaction using an OTP (one-time password) sent to their registered mobile number or email address. For transactions below Rs. 5000, 2FA is still recommended for enhanced security.
normalised: The R-B-I also emphasized the importance of two-factor authentication (two F-A) for all online payments exceeding rupees five thousand. This means that in addition to entering card details, customers will need to verify the transaction using an O-T-P (one-time password) sent to their registered mobile number or email address. For transactions below rupees five thousand, two F-A is still recommended for enhanced security.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the new guidelines introduce stricter norms for payment aggregators (PAs) and payment gateways (PGs). These entities, which facilitate online transactions, will now be required to undergo regular security audits and adhere to stringent data localization requirements. The goal is to ensure that customer data is stored securely within India, minimizing the risk of cross-border data breaches. Some PAs charge a fee of about 2% per transaction.
normalised: Furthermore, the new guidelines introduce stricter norms for payment aggregators (P-As) and payment gateways (P-Gs). These entities, which facilitate online transactions, will now be required to undergo regular security audits and adhere to stringent data localization requirements. The goal is to ensure that customer data is stored securely within India, minimizing the risk of cross-border data breaches. Some P-As charge a fee of about two percent per transaction.

unnormalised: Consumers are advised to update their payment preferences on e-commerce platforms and familiarize themselves with the new security measures. While these changes may initially cause some inconvenience, they are crucial for safeguarding digital transactions and building a more secure online payment ecosystem in India. The RBI expects these measures to reduce fraud by at least 30% in the next year.
